Award.AwardTitle: Electromagnetic Properties and Hadronic Parity Violation in Lattice QCD
Award.AbstractNarration:
Quarks are elementary particles that are strongly bound inside protons and neutrons. The residual strong interactions between protons and neutrons give rise to all of nuclear physics, from the simplest nuclear reactions responsible for fusion, to the intricate structure of large unstable nuclei. In essence, nuclei are to the strong 'chromodynamic' force what molecules are to the electromagnetic force. Tremendous progress is being made by solving the theory of strong interactions numerically. Current computing power and algorithms have put one within reach of realistic computations. Quantitative knowledge of the strong force will ultimately render nucleons and nuclei into laboratories for investigating fundamental symmetries and probing the limits of the Standard Model of particle physics. The comprehensive research program of the PI will combine advances in theoretical physics and high-performance computing to help advance our knowledge about nucleons and nuclei to the most advanced level yet. Moreover, the scope of this program affords both student and post-doctoral researchers considerable opportunities for training in nuclear and computational science, two areas in which an advanced technical workforce is much needed.

The scientific goal of this project is to study electromagnetic and parity-violating properties of strongly bound systems directly from Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). The distribution of charge and magnetism within nucleons will be explored by calculating their magnetic moments and electromagnetic polarizabilities using lattice gauge theory. Effort will also be geared toward studying the electromagnetic structure of light nuclei and hyper-nuclei using lattice QCD techniques, including the challenge of reducing the quark mass. Manifestations of the weak interaction at low energies will additionally be investigated from QCD. The parity-violating component of non-leptonic weak interactions introduces hadronic parity violation, and probes quark-quark correlations deep within hadrons. Due to feasibility of lattice QCD computations in the isotensor channel, lattice renormalization of isotensor parity violation will be determined and electromagnetic mixing will be addressed for the first time. Novel methods will be sought for future lattice calculations in the remaining isospin channels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded the research of principal investigator, Brian C. Tiburzi, for a duration of three years, and an additional three months during a no-cost extension period. Funds were utilized to provide partial support for a post-doctoral research fellow, Johannes Kirscher. Also included in this funding was financial support for the work of physics doctoral student Amol Deshmukh. Additionally, one masters-level student, and four undergraduate students were also mentored by the PI, and worked on aspects of this project.  

Professor Tiburzi's research concerns the theory of strong interactions, which is known by the name Quantum Chromodynamics, or QCD for short. This theory describes the internal workings of atomic nuclei. While nuclei are ultimately built from particles called quarks and gluons, these particles are strongly bound within the protons and neutrons that make up the nucleus. Free quarks and gluons do not share the same behavior as quarks and gluons strongly bound inside protons and neutrons. As a consequence, unraveling the quark and gluon structure of protons and neutrons is notoriously difficult. The PI employs state-of-the-art methods in computational physics to solve the theory of strong interactions numerically. This technique is known as Lattice QCD; and, it is, at heart, a multi-disciplinary endeavor that combines theoretical physics, high-performance computing, and data science. Funding from this project enabled new Lattice QCD methods to be developed, and the first-ever Lattice QCD computations of weak-interaction processes in light nuclei. 

A highlight of this project, the PI, in conjunction with the Nuclear Physics Lattice QCD collaboration (NPLQCD), pursued several ground-breaking computations. Building on previous success in calculating the magnetic structure of light nuclei with Lattice QCD, the PI and collaborators carried out computations of the axial structure of light nuclei. The axial-vector current gives rise to beta-decay of nuclei, for example, and NPLQCD computed the tritium beta-decay process for the first time using Lattice QCD (albeit at larger-than-physical values of the quark masses). The proton-proton fusion reaction, which ignites the fusion chain in our Sun, was another pioneering calculation carried out with the help of this grant. Experimentally, this particular reaction cannot be studied directly on Earth, and model-independent calculations provide indispensable input. These successful Lattice QCD studies pave the way for more refined computations that will further impact our understanding of solar and neutrino physics.  

The research undertaken in this project provided professional development for students and young scientists. Investigations carried out by research fellow Johannes Kirscher contributed to advancing the effective field theory techniques necessary to connect results from Lattice QCD computations to the physics of light nuclei. These superb studies helped him secure a further post-doctoral research fellowship at Manchester University in the United Kingdom (Fall 2018). Amol Deshmukh, under the mentor-ship of the PI, was awarded the Ph.D. degree in physics after successfully defending his dissertation (Fall 2018), and is currently pursuing a career in data science. Gaurav Verma, a Queens College Masters student, solidified his applications to doctoral programs as a result of completing an investigation under this project. He enrolled in the physics doctoral program at the University of Hawaii (Fall 2017). Three undergraduate students from the Macauley Honors College at The City College of New York were awarded Bachelor of Science degrees with the distinction of research honors due to their work on this project. One of these students, Anastasia Spiridonova, is pursuing a doctoral degree in physics at The City University of New York (Fall 2018).
